themes.title: Porcelain as a Cultural Connector
points: Discuss the global appeal of Yuan dynasty porcelain, such as the yuhuchun bottles, which were exported to regions as far as Kenya and Europe.
Highlight the Fonthill Vase, one of the earliest Chinese porcelain pieces to reach Europe, emphasizing its journey and cultural significance.
Explain how porcelain served as diplomatic gifts, like the celadon dish presented to Lorenzo de' Medici by the Mamluk Sultan of Egypt in 1487.

themes.title: Symbolism and Design in Porcelain
points: Explore the symbolism of green in Qing dynasty famille verte wares, which were prized for their imperial and auspicious associations.
Point out the Islamic-inspired designs on Yuan dynasty yuhuchun bottles, showcasing the cultural exchange between China and the Islamic world.
Discuss the scrolling floral patterns on Song dynasty qingbai wares, which were influenced by contemporary metalwork and lacquer designs.

themes.title: Innovative Techniques in Porcelain Production
points: Explain the Yuan dynasty's use of imported cobalt blue for underglaze decoration, made possible by reopened trade routes.
Describe the firing technique of qingbai wares, where bowls were fired upside down to save kiln space and prevent deformation.
Highlight the use of copper or silver rims to cover rough, unglazed areas on qingbai vessels, demonstrating practical and aesthetic solutions.

themes.title: Porcelain and Social Status
points: Discuss how porcelain, such as Yuan dynasty blue-and-white wares, was highly prized by the upper echelons of Chinese society.
Explain the appeal of Qing dynasty famille verte wares at the imperial court in Beijing and among European collectors.
Highlight the role of qingbai wares as utilitarian items for daily use and elaborate burial objects, reflecting their versatility and value.

themes.title: Hands-On Engagement: Spot the Details
points: Ask students to identify the green enamel on Qing dynasty famille verte wares and discuss its significance.
Encourage students to look closely at the cobalt blue designs on Yuan dynasty yuhuchun bottles and compare them to modern patterns.
Challenge students to find evidence of firing techniques, such as rough rims or copper finishes, on qingbai wares in the exhibit.
